Shays did a double take when CNBC told him how much money Basel said he handled in Iraq.
“Wait, one person?” Shays asked. “One person received $40 billion?”
Asked what he thinks about that, Shays said, “It just blows you away.”

text: Seems like a possibility, but Mueller could be constrained by grand jury secrecy and classification issues. Depending on the tone of the report, those could become a political football as one side or the other pushes for more disclosure to score political points.
author: EamonJavers

text: Once Barr decides, the public will know more, but not necessarily everything. If the WH thinks it is a good report for them politically, will they push Mueller/Barr to issue a Comey-style public explanation of why the president is innocent or uncharged?
author: EamonJavers

text: And then ... nothing. For several days at least, while Barr digests the Mueller report and decides what to do. We could have a frantic few days where the media, the public and the White House know Mueller is done, but don’t know what he’s found. Massive interest and few facts.
author: EamonJavers

text: Based on what I’m hearing, one scenario for how this will unfold is that we would get a terse announcement from DOJ that Mueller has submitted findings to Barr. That’s either before OR after Trump’s Vietnam trip, but not expected to be while he is overseas.

text: Thanks. These things vary. The president often does want to talk and take questions. It can be awkward when aides are shouting for reporters to leave while the president is still talking. Reporters don’t want to go while he is still speaking, in case he makes news.
author: EamonJavers

text: Also, oppo researchers do pass on gossip - I’ve been in national D and R offices where researchers have told me what they’re “hearing” from people “around town.” Clearly comes from source development on their part. But the vast majority of oppo is open records searching, etc.
author: EamonJavers

text: This good, BUT: the PI stuff is rare but it does happen. Once, an outside researcher handed me a document with coffee rings on it. He wouldn’t say where he’d gotten it, but it was clear his team had been dumpster diving the target’s trash. That happens.

text: I asked former NSA Director Admiral Mike Rogers about this issue just this afternoon. He said: “So first, I would worry less about the specifics of a particular report, ‘cause there were some things there that I thought weren't totally accurate.”
author: EamonJavers

text: We also talked about how reliable Turkish intelligence is and what he makes of the president’s tariff strategy against the Chinese. We’ll have more from my conversation with Admiral Rogers soon on @CNBCClosingBell.
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked Rogers if President Trump was right when he said the Chinese are attempting to meddling in the midterms. He said they are using “influence and other things,” but “I did not see them attempt to change outcomes or to try to drive outcomes in a way we saw the Russians do.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Rogers added: “This is something the government across the spectrum of government capabilities and organizations is clearly focused on. The indictment is an example of that.”
author: EamonJavers

text: After Friday’s criminal complaint against a Russian national for trying to influence the 2018 midterms, I asked Rogers how safe next month’s election will be. He said: “I don't think there should be any doubt in the mind of any citizen this clearly is a priority.“

text: Of Saudi Arabia, Admiral Rogers said: “These are not the actions that we believe a friend and ally should engage in. They're just not. And we need to convey that very strongly.”

text: DOJ says Russian trolls wrote on topics from sometimes opposing perspectives. Conspirators were directed, among other things, to create “political intensity through supporting radical groups” and to “aggravate the conflict between minorities and the rest of the population.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Among the issues the covert Russian social media effort sought to stoke discontent around were immigration, gun control and the Second Amendment, the Confederate flag, race relations, LGBT issues, the Women’s March, and the NFL national anthem debate, says DOJ.
author: EamonJavers

text: DOJ says Khusyaynova helped conduct “information warfare against the United States" designed to spread distrust towards candidates for U.S. political office and the U.S. political system in general.
author: EamonJavers

text: DOJ says Elena Alekseevna Khusyaynova, 44, of St. Petersburg, Russia, was a key player in something called “Project Lakhta,”which the government calls a Russian umbrella effort funded by oligarch Yevgeniy Prigozhin.

text: Kudlow: “You know me, I want everybody to get rich. And I want the non-rich to get rich.... I think this picture looks as good as it’s looked in years.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Kudlow on @CNBC: “Is the Fed crazy? Is that an institutional question or a personal question? ... Look, the president has his own views.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Kudlow on a possible Trump-Xi meeting at the G20: “They have lots to talk about, so we’ll see.” Says it’s not finalized yet.
author: EamonJavers

text: Looks like they fixed it quick. It was a headline and then text that was obviously a note from an editor reminding someone to add the reporters’ handles. And it ended with “cheers!” Some wires got crossed somewhere. It happens!
author: EamonJavers

text: When editors’ notes make it into the tweet text ... https://twitter.com/ap/status/1050326652209831936 …
author: EamonJavers

text: This fabulous piece by ⁦@Olivianuzzi⁩ captures a president who processes the media as the metric that measures his presidency even as he decries “fake news.” And read all the way to the truly Trumpian kicker:
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump after the stock market sell off: the “Fed has gone crazy.”
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump has been briefed on the market sell off this afternoon. A senior White House official gives me this comment now: “This is a bull market correction. It’s probably healthy. This will pass and the US economy remains strong.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Assistant AG says: “This case ...is part of an overall economic policy of developing China at American expense.  We cannot tolerate a nation’s stealing our firepower and the fruits of our brainpower.  We will not tolerate a nation that reaps what it does not sow.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Release says the unsealing follows the alleged spy’s extradition from Belgium. But I don’t immediately see the date he was extradited. The case also dovetails with what POTUS has been saying about the Chinese corporate espionage problem.
author: EamonJavers

text: Couple of interesting pieces to this: DOJ identifies this person explicitly as a Chinese Ministry of State Security operative, and officials arrested him on April 1 but are just unsealing the indictment now. Looks like the case involved alleged espionage against GE Aviation:
author: EamonJavers

text:
The official said the WH is more focused on the incoming hurricane right now than the markets: 
“We’re more concerned about the loss of life in Florida.”
author: EamonJavers

text:
I just spoke to a senior administration official with the Dow down 500. He said the WH is “monitoring” the markets but is “not concerned.”  
“There are reasons for these things,” he said. “We’re not concerned when it goes up 500, and not concerned when it goes down 500.”
author: EamonJavers

text: POTUS must dislike ABC twice as much as every other network... :)
author: EamonJavers

text: Powerful moment:
author: EamonJavers

text: She’s not running:
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked President Trump about interest rates a few minutes ago. He said he thinks they’re too high, particularly because there’s no inflation, but also said that he has not talked to Fed Chair Jay Powell about it because he doesn’t want to get involved.
author: EamonJavers

text: I’m the one tweeting ...
author: EamonJavers

text: Pompeo also praises Niki Haley before turning back into the White House without answering any questions from the assembled reporters. Very brief appearance here.
author: EamonJavers

text: Pompeo: “we can now see a path” to our ultimate goal of denuclearizing North Korea.
author: EamonJavers

text: White House just announced that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will speak to reporters on the driveway in 15 minutes.
author: EamonJavers

text: Also raising eyebrows inside the White House is the fact that Haley is leaving the Administration before the election, rather than after. That gives her the possibility of campaigning for other candidates and boosting her own political base before the election.
author: EamonJavers

text: People notice that Nikki Haley informing the president she would leave about six months ago dovetails with the timing of Mike Pompeo getting Secretary of State, a position that would have been a promotion for Haley.
author: EamonJavers

text: Some noticed a pattern of Haley getting out ahead of the President on policy, including her attempt to focus a recent UN meeting on Iran and on Russian sanctions. Remember her curt reply to Larry Kudlow: “With all due respect, I don’t get confused.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Despite Trump’s words of praise for Nikki Haley just now, I’m picking up on a strain of criticism of her inside the White House among at least some officials. The criticism goes like this:
author: EamonJavers

text: Haley on her presidential aspirations: “No I’m not going to be campaigning for 2020, I can tell you that what I’ll be doing is campaigning for this one,” she says, pointing to the president.
author: EamonJavers

text: Haley: “I don’t have anything set on where I’m going to go... I’m a believer in term limits.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Haley on Kushner: “Jared is such a hidden genius that no one understands.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Haley: “This has been the honor of a lifetime.... look at what has happened in the two years ... now the United States is respected.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump to Haley: “Hopefully you’ll be coming back at some point, maybe in a different capacity - you can take your pick.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on Haley: “She has done an incredible job. She is a fantastic person.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Nikki Haley just walked past reporters in the West Wing, but declined to respond to questions about whether or not she is resigning.
author: EamonJavers

text:
False Kanye alarm! 
Per pool: “Sarah just apologized and informed the TV pool that this Kanye visit is indeed happening on THURSDAY, not today.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Here’s my exchange about the NYT investigation with President Trump:
author: EamonJavers

text:
This section of today’s transcript really captures what it’s like to shout questions on the South Lawn amid all that helicopter noise: 
“Q    (Inaudible.)
THE PRESIDENT:  I don’t hear you.  What?”
author: EamonJavers

text: I followed up, asking if it was more than the relatively low $1 million he has said he received from his father. President Trump replied: “That’s been documented for many years. All public documents.” (The NYT reported he received more than $400 million in today’s dollars.)
author: EamonJavers

text: In light of the NYT investigation, I asked President Trump just now how much money he got from his father to get his start in business. He didn’t give a figure, saying instead: “That’s very well documented, very well documented.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I don’t know this bot, this is nonsense, and I have reported no such thing. Just so we’re all clear.
author: EamonJavers

text: Thank you sir!
author: EamonJavers

text: Weekend.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Collins: “I will vote to confirm Judge Kavanaugh.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Collins: “The #MeToo movement is real. It matters. And it is long overdue.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Collins: “Fairness will dictate that the claims at least should meet a threshold of more likely than not... The allegation failed to meeet the more likely than not standard.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Collins on Dr. Ford: “I believe that she is a survivor of a sexual assault and that this trauma has upended her life.” But Collins points to an absence of witnesses who can back up Dr. Ford’s testimony.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Collins: “We will be ill served in the long run if we abandon the presumption of innocence ... as tempting as it might be.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked Larry Kudlow where he was in December 1969, the last time unemployment was this low. He said he was in college, trying to get a job.
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow now on the good economic numbers: “I think it’s going to go on for quite some time. We have changed the face of the economy.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow says: “I think companies should pay up.” He would like to see wage increases from companies looking to hire in a tighter labor market.
author: EamonJavers

text: Wait - what? “I swear to God, there was a time I thought he would pick Judge Judy.”

text: I’ll be honest. I thought this person would be exposed in 48 hours. Astonished he/she has not been.

author: EamonJavers

text: Asked about the planned meeting between President Trump and Rod Rosenstein to decide the Deputy AG’s fate: “We don’t have any updates on that front. If there’s a meeting we’ll let you know.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sarah Sanders on the Kavanaugh nomination: “This entire process has been a disgrace.” She blames the Democrats.

text: It’s not every newspaper article that immediately becomes a Showtime documentary special.  But it looks like the NYT expose on Trump family taxes just did:
author: EamonJavers

text: This is the sentence that the president will hate most of all in this epic NYT investigation: “Donald Trump, master dealmaker, sold his father’s empire for hundreds of millions less than it was worth.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow just told reporters Google CEO Sundar Pichai committed to coming to the White House for a conference with social media and Internet companies that President Trump will preside over. WH hopes it will include Facebook and Twitter. No date yet.

text: Will he have to get a move on before the sun?
author: EamonJavers

text: Kushner said Trump knows the outcome he’s looking for when he uses that kind of language and is focused on results.
author: EamonJavers

text: In the Roosevelt Room just now I asked Jared Kushner about his father in law’s tough rhetoric and sometimes insulting language toward foreign leaders in negotiations. Is that personal, or just business? He said: “The president is very instinctive and also very deliberate.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “It’s one of my only good traits- I don’t drink...Can you imagine if I had what a mess I’d be?”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “Without tariffs we wouldn’t be standing here right now.” Says he’s mentioning that “for all the babies out there.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “I plan to sign the agreement by the end of November.” Says he will submit it to Congress where “in theory there should be no trouble,” but jokes there’s always trouble in Congress.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “We will be manufacturing many more cars. And our companies will no longer be leaving the United States.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Ice cream gets a nice round of applause in the Rose Garden.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on Trudeau: “A lot of stories came out about Justin and I having difficulty together.” But says this has turned out to be a very very good deal for both.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on the president of Mexico: “we have a few disagreements but I really like him a lot. He may like me as well, I’m not sure.”
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump: “USMCA - it has a good ring to it.” Says he has kept a key campaign promise with the agreement last night.
author: EamonJavers

text: White House getting set up for the president’s remarks in a few moments. We’re told these are USTR and National Economic Council staffers who will appear with President Trump in the Rose Garden.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH reporter slang. A “gaggle” is an informal q and a session with senior administration officials. Reporters gather around and fire off questions. Not sure where the term comes from but it goes way, way back.
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked Kudlow what concessions the United States made in the NAFTA negotiation, but he didn’t want to offer any specific examples. He said simply that there was a lot of coming together and good negotiation.
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow gaggling on the driveway now: “We’re sending China a message. They’re not going to break up the allies... We are showing them our progress around the world.”
author: EamonJavers

text: SEC: ELON MUSK SETTLES SEC FRAUD CHARGES; TESLA CHARGED WITH AND RESOLVES SECURITIES LAW CHARGE. Settlement Requires Musk to Step Down as Tesla’s Chairman; Tesla to Appoint Additional Independent Directors; Tesla and Musk Agree to Pay $40 million in Penalties
author: EamonJavers

text: Weekend.
author: EamonJavers

text: Statement from Brett Kavanaugh: “I’ve been interviewed by the FBI, I’ve done a number of “background” calls directly with the Senate, and yesterday, I answered questions under oath about every topic the Senators and their counsel asked me. (I) will  continue to cooperate.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Statement from President Trump: “I’ve ordered the FBI to conduct a supplemental investigation to update Judge Kavanaugh’s file. As the Senate has requested, this update must be limited in scope and completed in less than one week.”
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump on the Senate deal to delay a floor vote on Kavanaugh: “I will be totally reliant on what Sen. Grassley and the group decides to do.”
author: EamonJavers

text: WH tells me POTUS still fully intends to hold the delayed meeting with Rod Rosenstein, but staff still doesn’t have a specific time and date for it. Seems clear it won’t happen until Kavanaugh is settled.
author: EamonJavers

text: My oldest son was born during this super bowl. We watched the halftime show from the hospital room. During the delivery the anesthesiologist kept updating me on the score from his phone. I had to tell him to knock it off and pay attention!
author: EamonJavers

text: Longer SEC: “The SEC’s complaint alleges that, in truth, Musk had not discussed specific deal terms with any potential financing partners, and he allegedly knew that the potential transaction was uncertain and subject to numerous contingencies.”
author: EamonJavers

text: That’s a very low bar to clear.
author: EamonJavers

text: Shorter SEC: Funding not secured.
author: EamonJavers

text: SEC press release now: “ELON MUSK CHARGED WITH SECURITIES FRAUD FOR MISLEADING TWEETS”
author: EamonJavers

text: Fascinating. Wall Street is watching this too:
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow asks Ivanka Trump: “Can you re-skill ex-TV broadcasters and National Economic Council Directors?” Ivanka replies: “we’re working on it.” Chuckles from the crowd.
author: EamonJavers

text: Ivanka Trump now: “We’re deeply passionate about this idea of re-skilling (workers) and why we’re able to do it now is because the economy is so hot.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Ivanka Trump and Secretary Mnuchin now joining the panel. Ivanka Trump says the president’s economic predictions were dismissed during the campaign but have been remarkable since the Administration began.
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow speaking now at the White House economic summit says the president’s economic program is designed “to end the war against success.” The program is to reward success, not punish it, he says.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sarah Sanders to the press pool: “The President spoke with Rod Rosenstein a few minutes ago and they plan to meet next week. They do not want to do anything to interfere with the hearing.”
author: EamonJavers

text: There are other things going on in Washington today, but the Administration is hosting an economic summit here on the White House complex. Set to begin shortly.
author: EamonJavers

text: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and OMB Director Mick Mulvaney are both on my flight back to DC this morning. So I will be conducting exclusives in the aisle once they roll the drinks cart through...
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump on Kavanaugh: “When you are guilty until proven innocent, it’s just not supposed to be that way.”

author: EamonJavers

text: Trump says the accusations against Kavanaugh could discourage quality candidates from seeking high office: “We have a country to run. We want the best talent in the world.”

text: “Oh, good - Sky News,” the president says to a British reporter. “Congratulations on the purchase.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on North Korea: “If you saw what was going on behind the scenes, I think you’d be very impressed. We were a country going to war. ... Millions of people would have been killed... right now we’re in a great position.”

text: I asked President Trump if he has evidence of Chinese meddling in the US election as he alleged today. He said he does have evidence but he is not prepared to release it now.

text: Asked if there’s a chance he would ever withdraw Kavanaugh, Trump says: “If I thought he was guilty of something like this, yeah sure.”

text: President Trump on not asking for a FBI investigation of allegations against Kavanaugh: “it’s not going to change any of the Democrats’ minds. They’re obstructionists, they’re con artists is what they are.” Says an FBI investigation wouldn’t have made a difference.

text: President Trump on the Fed raising interest rates today: “I am not happy about that, because I know it’s going to be a question. I am not happy about that.”

text: Fair point. About half of Americans don’t vote. I have often wondered what our politics would look like if turnout was 70, 80 or 90 percent. Much, much different is my guess.

text: That seems grim! But it, too, will probably only be temporary as people grown numb, bored or cynical about the ways in which they are being provoked. What comes after that? I dunno. You tell me.

text: What does that portend for politics and culture? If other pols and brands reach the same conclusion, you could see a much more deliberately provocative society. As if your Twitter mentions metastasized through the national conversation.
author: EamonJavers

text: ... in an increasingly polarized society, there’s money to be made - and presidential elections to win - in hyper energizing the fringes. There’s more of them now on either side, and centrists are hard to hyper energize. They’re centrists, after all.
author: EamonJavers

text: It strikes me that Nike has just learned the same lesson that the Trump campaign taught us in ‘16. For generations, politicians and brands wanted to be at the center - that’s where most people were. The alleged MJ comment “Republicans buy sneakers too,” etc. But ...

text: BUT the camp that sees the comments as erratic appears to be second-hand sources. The Times cites people "briefed either on the events themselves or on memos written by FBI officials." The in-the-room person who saw the remark as sarcastic was provided to the Times by a DOJ spox.

text: One thing leaps out: there appear to be two camps of people who witnessed the same set of remarks. One camp saw the alleged remarks as “an example of how erratically he [Rosenstein] was behaving,” but another person in the room said Rosenstein only made the remark sarcastically.

author: EamonJavers

text: They do come from legitimate sources. That’s a bedrock principle and there are checks and balances inside these organizations to make sure. There can be fraud and cheating in any human endeavor. But there have been huge consequences for those caught: Stephen Glass, Jayson Blair.
author: EamonJavers

text: First, you know who the source is, so you know is they are in a position to know- were they in the room at the time, etc. Then you check it  against other sources, documents you can obtain and the public record.
author: EamonJavers

text: Right. The fact that it’s op-ed people and not reporters is another level of weirdness. I don’t know what their rules would be, and I’ve written for the NYT op-ed page.
author: EamonJavers

text: Right. But puts the organization in the ugly situation of not covering a lie. Not where a journalist wants to be. So the answer is no, but through gritted teeth.
author: EamonJavers

text: That said, if an anonymous source lies to the reporter, and the reporter discovers the lie after publishing false information, I believe the reporter could have an obligation to correct the record and reveal the source.
author: EamonJavers

text: I think the answer is no, or would be for a reporter (as opposed to the opinion desk). Sources deny being sources all the time. It’s one of the tricky problems of anonymous sourcing (though I argue anonymous sources are often necessary to get true information.)
author: EamonJavers

text: Journalistic ethics question: If the person who wrote the op-ed publicly denies they were the author, does the NYT Op-ed Department have an obligation to tell us?
author: EamonJavers

text: Yes - this is Washington, after all. And remember Mark Felt denied being Deep Throat before admitting it decades later. But this is a different era, and my guess is the writer knows his or her position is ultimately untenable. I don’t think this will take as long as Deep Throat.
author: EamonJavers

text: This is quickly becoming a process of elimination.
author: EamonJavers

text: A White House official this morning insists there has been no 25th amendment talk inside the Trump Cabinet. Also says the White House has no concerns about command and control of the administration - says the president is in charge here at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked fmr longtime Coats aide if Lodestar cd be Coats. He said: “I doubt it. Not his style. He’s the kind of guy who will share news in private but at the end of the day he’s really focused on what’s best for the country. Sounds trite but he’d make his feelings known to POTUS.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I think we can all, left and right, agree that “Lodestar” is a far more respectable nickname than “Deep Throat.”
author: EamonJavers

text: And it raises the further question of just what the person who wrote the oped was trying to accomplish. Is this ultimately an attempt to get the votes - either in the administration or in Congress? Or is this simply someone trying to protect their own legacy?
author: EamonJavers

text: That doesn’t require a vote, but it does raise serious questions of command and control of the administration - who, exactly, is running things at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue?
author: EamonJavers

text: But what both the book and the oped suggest is happening here is officials finding ways outside the constitution to resist a president they have decided is unfit to carry out at least some of his duties.
author: EamonJavers

text: The Constitution provides for two mechanisms to deal with an unfit president - the 25th amendment and impeachment. Both require a vote - of the department officers inside the administration or inside Congress.
author: EamonJavers

text: The Woodward book and Lodestar paint a picture of key people in the Administration ignoring presidential orders, stealing documents from the president and actively working to thwart him. These are not remedies envisioned in the Constitution.
author: EamonJavers

text: Is this a constitutional crisis? I don’t think it rises to that level. At least not yet. But you could call it an *unconstitutional* crisis.
author: EamonJavers

text: It’s not Paul Ryan - he’s not in the Administration.
author: EamonJavers

text: Intriguing. But would an FBI director be as focused on things like tax cuts and foreign policy? OTOH, Deep Throat did turn out to be the #2 at FBI...
author: EamonJavers

text: That would be a plot twist and a half.
author: EamonJavers

text: Technically meets definition of “senior administration official,” yes. But I wonder if he’s too low level for the the NYT to have taken such a dramatic step with him.
author: EamonJavers

text: The person sure spoke as if s/he is part of a group. Makes you wonder how the other members of the group feel about this- did they authorize this public reveal, or are they now terrified of the backlash?
author: EamonJavers

text: No. Way. That plot twist would be too twisty for even this administration.
author: EamonJavers

text: Good morning, 4 am Twitter! I’ll be back on CNBC at the top of the hour talking about what everyone in Washington is talking about: that op-ed. Quick, give me your theories - who wrote it?

text: All of official Washington has become a giant game of Clue: “Colonel Mustard, in the Cabinet Room ...”

text: Sanders says the author “has chosen to deceive, rather than support, the duly elected President of the United States.  He is not putting country first, but putting himself and his ego ahead of the will of the American people.  This coward should do the right thing and resign.”

text: Sanders statement now: “We are disappointed, but not surprised, that the paper chose to publish this pathetic, reckless, and selfish op-ed.  This is a new low for the so-called “paper of record,” and it should issue an apology...”

text: Yep. If you tell a reporter something is off the record and then you convey important high level information, you definitely do intend to be a source!
author: EamonJavers

text: Off the record is an agreement between a source and a reporter. The Toronto paper didn’t make any agreement with POTUS. So once they got the story, they weren’t breaking any agreement by publishing it.
author: EamonJavers

text: Not just yet. Wait for it...
author: EamonJavers

text: That’s a good way to get tips source doesn’t want to be connected to. Reporters can find other sources to confirm the info. Both categories are loosely referred to as Anonymous Sources. Clearly POTUS intended to be a source for the fact that US is offering no concessions.
author: EamonJavers

text: Good question. 2 categories: “on background” agreement means reporters use the statement but not the name of the source. You see that as coming from a “senior administration official,” etc. “Off the record” means it’s just for the reporter’s info, not to be reported 1/2
author: EamonJavers

text: It’s not at all clear this leak came from Bloomberg. No solid info on who did this. I know both reporters in question and they are rock solid. Leak could also have come from the Administration, or a technical comms glitch.
author: EamonJavers

text: I don’t. I was too loosely referring to either a tape or a transcript of the tape. But yeah, a transcript probably had wider circulation than the tape itself. Note that the Star said it wasn’t able to 100% confirm the remarks. To me that indicates transcript. But who knows?

text: Watch for this fight to continue through the day today. My sense is it will come down to a dispute over how many hours *in advance* Google did or did not promote Trump’s 2018 State of the Union. author: EamonJavers

text: Of course, the downside risk is impeachment. High risk, high reward! Trump’s entire political existence is based on doubling down on high political risk, so it’s familiar territory for him.

text: Losing Congress would give Trump a plausible political enemy back - it’s not paranoia if they really are out to get you! Lower expectations for governing/legislating + higher expectations from the base for a fighter = political upside.
author: EamonJavers

text: Because Trump is a politician who thrives when he has a foil - a political enemy to grapple with. In that sense, 2016 was a catastrophic success for Trump, because he won total control, without a powerful enemy in sight.
author: EamonJavers

text: That’s a good one! Not sure the WH is prepared for what could hit them here. That said, I have a counterintuitive take: losing Congress could be GOOD for Trump, no matter how inimical...

text: Speaker Paul Ryan statement: “Insider trading is a clear violation of the public trust. Until this matter is settled, Rep. Collins will no longer be serving on the House Energy and Commerce Committee.”
author: EamonJavers

text: The son allegedly sold stock ahead of the bad news, and passed on info to friends and family who also sold stock. The congressman allegedly broke his duty of confidentiality to the company as a board member by passing on the information in the first place.
author: EamonJavers

text: Indictment says that Collins himself did not trade on the news and personally lost millions of dollars in stock value when the drug trial results came out.
author: EamonJavers

text: After bad drug trial results for the company, Innate's stock declined 92%. Indictment says Collins got an email about the news before it was released while he was at the Congressional picnic in 2017, and called his son to pass on the news minutes later.
author: EamonJavers

text: Indictment says Collins passed material, nonpublic drug trial results to his son and that subsequent stock trades allowed a group of friends and family to avoid over $768,000 in losses they would have otherwise incurred.
author: EamonJavers

text: Collins attorneys say they "will mount a vigorous defense to clear his good name.  It is notable that even the government does not allege that Congressman Collins traded a single share of Innate Therapeutics stock.   We are confident he will be completely vindicated +exonerated."
author: EamonJavers

text: I'm not sure the STOCK Act applies here: According to the indictment, Collins was a member of the board who had confidentiality obligations to the company's insider information. Those rules would have applied whether he was a member of Congress or not.
author: EamonJavers

text: WNBC’s @jonathan4ny reporting that NY Congressman Chris Collins has been arrested by the FBI on securities fraud charges. US attorney in NY sets presser for noon on charges against Collins relating to Innate Immunotherapeutics, on whose board of directors Collins served.

text: You might want to pick up a copy of my book. I interviewed John Brennan in between his stints at the CIA back in 2008. At the time, he was at a small firm called The Analysis Corporation. He offered his thoughts on former officers working in the private sector.
author: EamonJavers

text: Not opining on whether it is valid or not. It is how thousands of people in washington earn a living, though. They say they’re not selling access, they’re selling skills. Take that for what you will.
author: EamonJavers

text: I’m not sure how often they get them renewed. Generally low level intel officials keep their security clearances as they go around from job to job in the intel contracting sector, unless they do something wrong. These people are all extremely senior of course.
author: EamonJavers

text: Intel consulting work, boards of directors of defense contractors. That sort of thing can be lucrative for former officials, and current security clearances can be crucial for getting that work.
author: EamonJavers

text: This is a big deal. Stripping a former CIA director of his security clearance will be seen as a grave insult to some in intel community. And there could be a financial impact: former officials depend on clearances to serve on boards of directors of defense contractors, etc.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sarah Sanders says President Trump is looking to strip security clearances from former CIA director Brennan as well as the following former officials: Comey, Clapper, Hayden, Rice and McCabe.

author: EamonJavers

text: I don’t think I’ve ever seen a statement from a senator about a president like this one from McCain just now: “No prior president has ever abased himself more abjectly before a tyrant.” Full statement here:  https://www.mccain.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=press-releases&id=A99FDA26-673D-4560-B4EA-5AEDF0685EC5 …
author: EamonJavers

author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if the Russian government has any compromising material on President Trump or his family, Putin says: “Yeah I do hear these rumors... when President Trump was in Moscow back, then I didn’t even know he was in Moscow.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if he will denounce Russian meddling in front of the world, Trump responds by asking for the release of the DNC server. Says: “All I can do is ask the question.” On US intelligence that Russia was behind the hack, Trump says: “I don’t see any reason why it would be.”
author: EamonJavers

text: *intelligence officials* not *officiated*. darn autocorrect.
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin on ways to get to the bottom of the indictment issue: “Options abound.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin says under treaty, Mueller can send a request and Russians will interrogate those intelligence officiated who have been indicted. Says US official could participate in that questioning, as long as Russians get to come to the US and question Americans.
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin, on the 12 Russian intelligence officers indicted by the special counsel last week: “I don’t know the full extent of the issue, but President Trump mentioned it and I will look into it.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin, asked why Americans should believe his denial of election meddling, says: “Where did you get this idea that President Trump trusts me and I trust him?” Adds that Trump represents the US and he represents Russia.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “To say it one time again- and I say it all the time: There was no collusion. I didn’t know the president then.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on the Mueller probe: “I think the probe was a disaster from our country.... there was no collusion. ... that was a clean campaign, I beat Hillar Clinton easily.”
author: EamonJavers

text: First question to Trump is from Interfax, and is about Trump’s critical comments about the Russian German gas pipeline.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump says he brought up the issue of US election interference by the Russians, says President Putin feels strongly about it and has “an interesting idea” about it.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “Our relationship has never been worse than it is now, however that changed as of about four hours ago. I really believe that.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on the summit: “It went very well.” Trump congratulates the Finns for hosting the summit and Putin for hosting the World Cup. Says: “A productive dialogue is not only good for the United States and good for Russia but it is good for the world.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin says Trump brought up what Putin refers to as “so-called interference” in the US election. He says he told Trump: “the Russian state has never interfered and is not going to interfere” on American internal matters.
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin criticizes American diplomacy in Ukraine: “The United States could be more decisive in nudging the Ukrainian leadership.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin says the Korean issue had begun to be resolved “thanks to the personal engagement of President Trump who opted for dialogue instead of confrontation.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin says the Russian side gave the US delegation a note with suggestions on how to improve the relationship between the two countries. Says the “special services” of both countries have been cooperating on a number of issues.
author: EamonJavers

text: Putin on summit: “I think we can call it a success. ... As major nuclear powers, we bear special responsibility for maintaining international security.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Unclear what just happened in the Helsinki press briefing room but TV feeds show someone just pulled out of the presser, with apparent security officers manhandling him and a scuffle breaking out.
author: EamonJavers

text: That’s Helsinki Cathedral which, according to Wikipedia, opened in 1852 originally to honor Tsar Nicholas I of Russia. Overlooks Senate Square. Very pretty.
author: EamonJavers

text: We are told the Trump-Putin one on one is still ongoing behind closed doors, nearly a half hour longer than expected so far. Here’s our view as we wait. Next up: a bilateral meeting with aides from both sides.
author: EamonJavers

text: Pro and anti-Trump protestors confronting each other here in Senate Square now. Pro-Trump protestor shouting into a megaphone at the anti-Trump group in pink: “Shame on you bastards! Marxists!” Trump and Putin meeting behind closed doors blocks away.
author: EamonJavers

text: Thanks. He was shot and wounded in the shoulder but survived. Went on to a long and successful career in journalism around the world.
author: EamonJavers

text: Yeah. It drives my dad nuts, as you can see from that clip. He’s big on getting the facts straight!
author: EamonJavers

text: It’s also a reminder of the risks journalists take to get the truth out to the world. They did it 40 years ago, and they are still doing it today. In other words: real news.
author: EamonJavers

text: It’s bizarre, actually, that the phrase “drinking the Kool-Aid” entered popular culture after Jonestown. Most people have no idea what horror they are invoking when they use that phrase.
author: EamonJavers

text: Tonight, NBC’s Dateline is airing a story about journalists who lost their lives covering Jonestown 40 yrs ago. An important reminder of what happens when people surrender free will to an all-powerful leader. My dad was there-that’s him on the right in the beard + floppy hat.

text: On the deficit, he said: “I think it will come down in 2018, and  the big reductions will come in future years.”

text: Of the people who criticized him today, Kudlow says: “Either they misunderstand or they are ideologically opposed to our program.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Larry Kudlow just called me to say that his comment today that the deficit “is coming down rapidly” was misinterpreted. “I was referring to future deficits,” he said. “I’ll stand by that... because we believe there’s an investment boom going on.”

text: Weekend.

text: White House declines to comment on General Motors saying today that potential vehicle tariffs from the Trump Administration could lead to “a smaller GM" and cost jobs.

text: President Trump, expressing sympathy for the victims of yesterday’s shooting in Annapolis says: “Journalists, like all Americans, should be free from the fear of being attacked while doing their jobs.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked WH legislative director Marc Short about the federal deficit increase since the tax cut. He said: “We’re very concerned about deficits. I think the administration has tried to address that. We hope that Congress will partner with us in actually cutting spending.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if President Trump is considering withdrawing from the WTO, WH legislative director Marc Short just said: “I’m not familiar with any plans right now at this point.”
author: EamonJavers

text: That’s great! These are troubled times, but journalists have covered a lot worse. Tell him: 1. Tell the truth. 2. Double check everything. 3. Try to think of the story as your editor will see it AND how the people you are writing about will see it. And good luck.

text: Justice Kennedy to retire from the Supreme Court, setting up an enormous opportunity for President Trump. The official statement: “Justice Kennedy today advised his colleagues that he is submitting to the President a formal notification of his decision, effective July 31”
author: EamonJavers

text: Behind the scenes at Supreme Court: Kim McIntyre, left, doing PR for free market Mackinac Center for Public Policy. She used these signs to attract reporters to interview her experts, who naturally agree with the Center’s position. All 3 were pleased with today’s Janus decision.

text: Trump now on space exploration: “Let the rich guys do it. You have all these rich guys who love rockets... let them be the first to Mars, and we’ll take all the credit.”

text: On the question of whether the president supports this FLOTUS trip, a spokesperson says: “This was her decision. She told her staff she wanted to go and we made that happen. He is supportive of it but she told him, `I’m headed down to Texas,’ and he supported it.”

author: EamonJavers

text: Interesting. Just did a quick Google News search + got a pop up from Google asking me if I was satisfied with results. If dissatisfied, it asked if I was upset the news sources were not well known or if the articles were presenting opinions as facts. First time I’ve seen that.

text: WH trade adviser Peter Navarro was just asked about NYT report the WH told Apple’s Tim Cook it will not place tariffs on IPhones. He said: “I have no knowledge or comment about that.” But he also said “the president will have the back of Americans” on the farm or in Shanghai.
author: EamonJavers

text: Exactly. But my sense is the WH is ready and willing to reply in kind. Neither Trump nor Xi can afford to be seen backing down.
author: EamonJavers

text: There are those inside the White House who felt Navarro would always win this debate, because in his heart the president is closer to Navarro’s view of the world than any other aide.
author: EamonJavers

text: This is a win for aides like trade hawks Lighthizer and Navarro, and a loss for others more skeptical like Mnuchin and Kudlow (who has been sidelined by his heart attack and not back to work since last week.)
author: EamonJavers

text: Also, against the scale of the US and Chinese economies, WH will feel that the tariffs are small potatoes- and that markets should look at the potential long term benefits for US IP if they succeed.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH will argue the Chinese can not match the $200 billion figure, because the Chinese only import $130 billion from the US and have already announced potential tariffs on $50B. Whereas the US imports $505B from China.
author: EamonJavers

text: Here’s my sense of the White House’s thinking on the new Chinese tariff announcement: They feel strongly that the Chinese have more to lose in this than the US does and they gave China every opportunity to change its behavior.
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump: “today, I directed the United States Trade Representative to identify $200B worth of Chinese goods for additional tariffs at a rate of 10 percent.  After the legal process is complete, these tariffs will go into effect if China refuses to change its practices.”

text: White House legislative affairs director Marc Short told staff this morning he will be leaving the White House. According to a WH official, Short said he has talked to the chief of staff about leaving at the end of the summer: “Nothing imminent though. Still a lot of work to do.”
author: EamonJavers

text: U.S. Chamber of Commerce President and CEO Thomas J. Donohue on President Trump’s tariffs: “This is not the right approach.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sanders said she doesn’t have any personnel announcements to make about herself, Raj Shah or Marc Short. But she also didn’t deny that any of the three are set to depart.
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked Sanders if she + others are leaving the WH. She said “each and every day I’ll pray for clarity +discernment on what my future looks like. Right now I think the country looks pretty good +I’m glad to get to be a part of that process and I’m going to continue to do my job.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sanders: “I am not today or tomorrow or at any point ever going to comment on Rudy Giuliani’s love life.”

text: Thanks for watching. Our job is to report the truth. Nothing else.

text: Here’s the scene now between the White House and Executive Office Building. We are being told a worker fell, but “he will be fine.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Secret Service says there’s a “medical emergency” on the White House complex. Two Hazmat trucks on scene now, multiple ambulances. They brought at least three emergency vehicles through the gates on West Executive Drive. Unclear what’s happening, but it is a robust response.

text: We’ve asked the White House who the four reporters are POTUS is talking about here. No answers yet. I know of 2 who saw the First Lady: me and @kwelkernbc. I tweeted about it May 30. There were no other reporters there at the time, but maybe POTUS is referring to something else?

text: I asked Larry Kudlow if he would tell the president the jobs number early next month out of concern it could leak out. Kudlow said: “I have no idea. It’s a judgment call. He is the president.” Kudlow said POTUS’ Tweet was not inappropriate.

text: I just asked Sarah Sanders if it was appropriate for President Trump to tweet about the jobs report before release this morning. She said it was, because “he didn’t put the numbers out.” She also confirmed that the President was briefed on the number last night.

text: All this happened at roughly the same time that more than 900 people were being murdered or committing suicide at Jones’ command back at the compound. That’s where the expression “drinking the Kool Aid” comes from, by the way. Don’t use it lightly.
author: EamonJavers

text: Some were killed instantly and some were wounded and unable to move. My dad, Jackie Speier and others were shot and wounded but able to make a harrowing escape into the jungle. The gunmen murdered the wounded who were not able to run for it.
author: EamonJavers

text: Cult members loyal to Jones leapt from a tractor and began firing. Ryan, defector Patricia Parks, NBC correspondent Don Harris and San Francisco Examiner photographer Greg Robinson were killed. Bob Brown, who filmed these images, was also killed.
author: EamonJavers

text: Everyone was jumpy. They could feel things spinning out of control. You can see my dad &Tim Reiterman frisking people at the plane - improvising security at direction of @RepSpeier, who was a young congressional staffer. They were worried someone might have a gun. Someone did.
author: EamonJavers

text: Things had gone badly at Jonestown - the place was seething with tension and hostility. Ryan decided it was time to get his people out, and led his staff, the reporters and some defectors from the cult to this airstrip to go home. They almost made it.
author: EamonJavers

text: The congressman was in Guyana to protect his constituents - Americans who had families in his congressional district. The journalists were there to find out what was going on and to tell the truth about it: Real news.
author: EamonJavers

text: What you see here is the delegation led by Congressman Leo Ryan evacuating Jonestown, where the evil cult leader Jim Jones had taken hundreds of followers to build a secluded compound. Some of the people in this video are about to die.
author: EamonJavers

text: While we are all having a conversation about journalism, here’s something the FBI posted last week. This is film taken by NBC’s Bob Brown on Nov. 18, 1978 on an airstrip near Jonestown, Guyana. That’s my dad, Ron Javers, in the floppy hat + big ‘70s beard.

author: EamonJavers

text: WH Chief of Staff John Kelly just walked around a corner in the West Wing and spotted a bunch of reporters. He said “hey, didja hear what happened?” We all looked up, startled. Then he chuckled and walked into Sarah Sanders office. Good one.

text: Statement from president’s lawyer: "John Dowd is a friend and has been a valuable member of our legal team. We will continue our ongoing representation of the President and our cooperation with the Office of Special Counsel.” - Jay Sekulow, Counsel to the President
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump didn’t get everything he wants on Wall spending. But a WH official says WH secured funding for 108 miles of “bollard wall”,  which the official calls “a step in the right direction.”
author: EamonJavers

text: The spending bill meeting was held in the White House residence for about 45 minutes today. President Trump was joined by the Vice President, chief of staff John Kelly, and Marc Short. Mitch McConnel dialed in on the phone.
author: EamonJavers

text: Goldman Sachs on expected Trump tariffs: “We believe retaliation is likely, and note that in some recent cases China has announced its own protective actions within days of a US action...”
author: EamonJavers

text: There are a bunch of professionals here who could shoot it better. But it’s a pretty building. Hard to take a bad picture of it!
author: EamonJavers

text: Snow day at the White House today. All public events cancelled.
author: EamonJavers

text: Absolutely stunning reporting here:
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec indicates that neither Russian meddling in the US election nor the alleged recent Russian poisoning of a spy in Britain came up in the conversation between Trump and Putin.
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if the Russian election was free and fair, Sanders says: “Look, in terms of the election, there we focus on our election, we don’t get to dictate how every country operates.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if the WH believes that the Russian election was a sham, @presssec answered a different question, saying, “We disagree with the fact that we shouldn’t have discussions with Russia.”
author: EamonJavers

text: “There are no specific plans made at this time,” says @presssec about a Trump-Putin meeting, but says US wants to continue to have a dialogue with the Russians. Earlier, President Trump said he would have a meeting with Putin.
author: EamonJavers

text: Per pool, President Trump just said he plans to get together with Russian leader Vladimir Putin in the not too distant future to discuss the “arms race.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Spotted: Hanging on the wall of the West Wing, new pictures of the President’s trip to the Middle East last year, and of Trump with Saudi dignitaries, just ahead of the MBS visit to the White House today.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH official on whether Trump team benefitted from Facebook/Cambridge Analytica data: “Not every campaign is aware of the actions of its vendors’ vendors.”
author: EamonJavers

text: White House official to me, on Facebook: “We expect the privacy rights of Americans to be protected.”
author: EamonJavers

text: One source familiar with president Trump’s legal team tells me no changes are expected today in wake of hiring of Joe diGenova. “Team is fully engaged,” source says. “Everyone is looking forward to having Joe on board.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Per Politico, Gary Cohn was at times a serious candidate for Secretary of State, Fed Chair, and .... CIA director.

text: @PressSec asked why, 15 months in, the president still wants to change out people in his cabinet, says: As policy priorities change sometimes you are going to have personnel change.
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec:  “No immediate personnel changes at this time.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec, on whether porn star Stormy Daniels was physically threatened by anyone connected with President Trump: “Obviously, we take the safety and security of any person seriously. “

text:
There seems to be an effort to calm the roiling waters here at the White House. One WH official tells me it seems like things are calming down. “Everything seems pretty chill this morning.”

But same official says that is subject to change at any time.
author: EamonJavers

text: Better double check it.

text: It’s a slippery slope, Ben...

author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec on the president’s bowling ball test remarks: “Look, the president has been talking about unfair trade practices for decades... obviously he’s joking about this particular example.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec on whether there is an air of chaos and vulnerability in the WH: “I certainly don’t think there are any vulnerabilities here.”

text: @presssec asked if Mueller subpoena of Trump org is a red line for POTUS: “There was no collusion between the campaign and Russia.” Refers questions to Trump Organization.

text: White House is referring all questions about the NYT report on the Mueller subpoena of the Trump Organization to the Trump Organization for comment.
author: EamonJavers

text: Yep. Larry is a regular attendee and public supporter of AA. (See @morningmoneyben ‘s recent podcast with him.) Just not the kind of language you often hear from people heading into big WH jobs.

text: Wait - was he the charming, handsome one with the Devil-may-care attitude?
author: EamonJavers

text: Certainly indicates a sense of fatalism about the job.
author: EamonJavers

text: Did anyone else key on this comment from Larry Kudlow yesterday as he heads into the tumultuous Trump administration? “However this thing works out, it will be God’s will.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Kudlow to me, on POTUS: “We’ve had tremendous conversations on this Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and even this morning. It’s been wonderful talking through a number of points and issues. He is intimately familiar with my views and I am intimately familiar with his views.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Kudlow to me: “The President and Kevin Brady have been talking about phase two on tax cuts. There may be more action on that front. Trade will be very important. Infrastructure will be very important. Immigration will be very important.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Kudlow to me, on potential disagreements with President Trump: “Once the decision is made, it’s made. I understand that. I may not agree with every crossed T or dotted I, but that no longer matters.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Tell me your real name and I will put in a good word for you.
author: EamonJavers

text: A source familiar with the decision tells me that President Trump offered Larry Kudlow the job as National Economic Council Director last night and Kudlow has accepted. Formal announcement could come as soon as tomorrow.
author: EamonJavers

text: This seems ominous...
author: EamonJavers

text: Good morning 4 am twitter! Lots of news to bring you up to speed on at the top of the hour. How’s everyone doing?

text: Ivan.
author: EamonJavers

text: I went totally rogue there for a minute.
author: EamonJavers

text: I just got an email with the subject line “Do Not Delete.” I deleted it. And I feel pretty good about that decision.
author: EamonJavers

text: I’m told that there are three things now under consideration at the WH: these tariffs, investment restrictions, and potential visa restrictions for travelers. It’s all aimed at China.
author: EamonJavers

text: Tillerson: “Much work remains to explain the troubling behavior and actions on the part of the Russian government.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Tillerson says he will turn over responsibilities to a deputy today, will wind up his official tenure later this month.
author: EamonJavers

text: Tillerson: “We remain steadfast here in Washington and at posts throughout the world.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Tillerson says he got a call today from POTUS at noon today on AF 1. That’s about 4 hours after the news broke that he’d been fired. Tillerson says he’s working on a smooth transition and encouraging staffers to remain at their posts. His commission ends at midnight.
author: EamonJavers

text: I am told not to expect an announcement on Larry Kudlow today. But as we’ve seen, things can change around here...
author: EamonJavers

text: That makes for an odd combination of empty chairs and lame ducks inside the West Wing.
author: EamonJavers

text: Pay attention to the big divide in the WH between those who are fired and immediately leave - like McEntee today - and those who resign but hang around the building for a few weeks. Gary Cohn, Josh Raffel and even Hope Hicks have all resigned but are still in the West Wing now.
author: EamonJavers

text: Yeah, body man is a thing. Literally the guy next to the principal who holds all his stuff, keeps him on schedule, runs interference, etc. You should get yourself one!
author: EamonJavers

text: They’re also looking for a new communications director and now apparently a new body man, too.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on the findings of the British government on the apparent Russian spy assassination attempt: “It sounds to me like they believe it was Russia and I would certainly take that finding as fact.” Says he will speak to PM May today.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “I think Rex will be much happier now.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on Tillerson: “We disagreed on things. When you look at the Iran deal, I think it was terrible, I guess he thinks it was OK.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on Pompeo: “We’re always on the same wavelength.” Says he needs someone he has a good relationship with at State.

text: POTUS confirms the Tillerson news:
author: EamonJavers

text: On nerve agent attack on Russian spy in England, @PressSec says WH is “monitoring the situation closely” and calls the attack an “outrage,” “reckless” and “irresponsible.”

text: I’m told the WH is considering pushing for legislation on the Hill to authorize POTUS to impose reciprocal tariffs country by country and product by product. POTUS has talked about this publicly, but some in WH want a bipartisan bill.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH says POTUS spoke with Xi Jinping of China today and the two “committed to maintain pressure and sanctions until North Korea takes tangible steps toward complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if HR McMaster would remain National Security Advisor through the NK negotiations, @PressSec says: “I have no reason to believe otherwise.” But also says: “I don’t have a crystal ball to predict the future.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec : “We are making no concessions.” Says US will not move forward without concrete steps by NK.
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec, asked if POTUS believes Kim Jong Un is sincere: “The president is hopeful that we can make some continued progress.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec on today’s jobs report: “The federal government is getting out of the way and the American people are building, innovating and creating jobs.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I think this may be the first time the president has gone to the briefing room.
author: EamonJavers

text: Aluminum worker Dustin Stevens says President Trump signed his helmet in the White House today.  Workers are making the case for tariffs at the WH now, explaining that any price increases will be more than offset by increased economic activity.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump to union leader: “Your father Herman is looking down, he’s very proud of you.” Union leader: “Oh, he’s still alive.” Trump: “He is? Well, then, he’s even more pleased.”

text: POTUS now quoting @elonmusk tweet on tariffs ...

author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “Rich guys, they love rocket ships. That’s good. It’s better than us paying for them.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on Cohn: “He’s been terrific. He may be a globalist, but I still like him.” Cabinet gives Cohn a round of applause. “He’s going to go out and make another couple hundred million,” but Trump says Cohn may come back in another role.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “Bump stocks are going to be gone.” Says the paperwork for banning them is almost finished.
author: EamonJavers

text: Very unsettled here at the WH, and it is not clear what POTUS will or won’t sign at the 3:30 event. But one official tells me Trump will sign legal paper enacting his objectives - and it will include dates of enactment and implementation. But others not confirming. Stay tuned.
author: EamonJavers

text: It is also confusing inside.
author: EamonJavers

text: Note that he calls it a “meeting,” not an “announcement.” The question of whether POTUS will finalize tariffs, and on what terms, is still open. What does “great flexibility” mean, exactly?
author: EamonJavers

text: Thanks for the vote of confidence! But I had to duck out to go on the air with the exemptions news...
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec on replacing Gary Cohn: “He’s going to take his time making that decision.”
author: EamonJavers

text: A virtuous economic cycle!
author: EamonJavers

text: I’m told the tariff details announcement Thursday or Friday could come at the same time as public WH conversations around additional trade actions beyond steel and aluminum.
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked by @ScottWapnerCNBC if the president has given Scaramucci the green light to attack John Kelly on TV, Scaramucci says “Has not and , not something I would even talk about.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Scaramucci, asked by @ScottWapnerCNBC if the president will have trouble hiring the best people says there is “Unlimited talent supply of people that want to work in the White House and will work for President Trump.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if Cohn’s departure is a loss, Scaramucci says, “The White House didn’t miss a beat when I left,” and Cohn is a way bigger loss than he was. But also quotes the old saw that graveyards are full of indespensible men.
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked if tariffs are a mistake, Scaramucci says, “Well, are they being imposed?” He says he can’t opine until they are actually imposed, but POTUS is a common sense person on the economy.
author: EamonJavers

text: Anthony Scaramucci on the air on @CNBC now, calling Gary Cohn a great team builder and incredibly smart.
author: EamonJavers

text: You’re so lazy, Wilf, sleeping in like that.

text: Cheers!
author: EamonJavers

text: Good morning three am twitter people! How’s everyone doing?
author: EamonJavers

text: Senior administration official tells me Gary Cohn’s departure came after 4-5 weeks of discussing his future in the Administration with Trump. It’s described to me as a mutual decision, and less to do with the tariff disagreement than people think.
author: EamonJavers

text: Of all the petty humiliations of Peter Navarro’s time out of favor in the Trump WH, one stood out: by order of Chief of Staff Kelly, he had to cc Gary Cohn on every White House email he sent. Now with Cohn out and tariffs in, Navarro is in the ascendency:
author: EamonJavers

text: But a separate WH source say not to discount Kudlow, even though he might disagree on trade.
author: EamonJavers

text: Administration source tells me top two candidates to replace Cohn will be Peter Navarro and Larry Kudlow - two men with VERY different views on trade.
author: EamonJavers

text: I’m told Gary Cohn told his staff yesterday to make sure the interns on his team got to do everything they wanted to do this week - which made people think he was buttoning up last details before leaving.
author: EamonJavers

text: White House officials told me this afternoon that IF Gary Cohn leaves it won’t only be because of the tariff decision. They were clearly laying the groundwork for this news.
author: EamonJavers

text: Not sure who was missing, but there was an empty chair in White House staff seating area at the presser today. I didn’t see Gary Cohn or Jared Kushner in the room, and they are usually both regular attendees.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “The Russians had no impact on our votes whatsoever, but certainly there was meddling.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on his management style: I like conflict. I like having two people with differing points of view, and I certainly have that.
author: EamonJavers

text: Asked to what you owe this new openness of the North Koreans to talk, president Trump replied: “Me.”
author: EamonJavers

text: It is me. But that’s not my best angle.
author: EamonJavers

text: Ha! That was what we call a cross talk, and I had a lot to cross talk about.
author: EamonJavers

text: I will never understand journalists who argue in favor of not interviewing sources.
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec, asked if the Russians intervened to block the appointment of Mitt Romney to a Trump administration role during the transition: “I’m not aware of anything regarding that.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec says the president will be meeting with representatives of the video game industry Thursday about gun violence.
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec, on Paul Ryan’s criticism of tariffs: “We have a great relationship with Speaker Ryan, we’re going to continue to have one, but that doesn’t mean we have to agree on everything.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec is introducing veterans who met with the president at Walter Reed and who are visiting the White House today.
author: EamonJavers

text: Watch the Dow today for what it says about politics - both the Nationalists and the Globalists have been using it behind the scenes in DC all day as evidence their argument about tariffs is right.
author: EamonJavers

text: That’s great. I offered to bring the pool drinks, but I think the world should know they declined because they don’t drink on duty. Total pros.
author: EamonJavers

text: That was quite something. Is the Gridiron still off the record?
author: EamonJavers

text: You’re welcome! Thanks for watching. Enjoy your weekend.
author: EamonJavers

text: Weekend.
author: EamonJavers

text: Wind is wreaking havoc on the TV tents here at the White House. CBS’s live shot position just collapsed. No one hurt.
author: EamonJavers

text: How many times can you threaten to resign before it loses credibility? Seems Cohn and Kelly have adopted that as a negotiating strategy w/ POTUS. But ultimately the president may not believe it, or may not care.
author: EamonJavers

text: Snow days, I get. But my kids have a wind day today.
author: EamonJavers

text: POTUS: “Trade wars are good, and easy to win.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Here’s context you are missing: Event was changed 2 hours ahead. WH told us no announcement would be made and no press would be let in. Then POTUS changed that plan again. Without notice, he scrambled pool reporters. Then he made the announcement we were told he would not make.
author: EamonJavers

text: Ha! Good to see you, too!
author: EamonJavers

text: Now a totally different tone from the NSC spox: “I was just with President Trump and H.R. McMaster in the Oval Office. President Trump said  that the NBC News story is ‘fake news,’ and told McMaster that he is doing a great job.” – Michael Anton, NSC Spokesman
author: EamonJavers

text: There are “non denial denials” in journalism. But this WH comment on McMaster is a non denial non denial: “We frequently face rumor and innuendo about senior administration officials. There are no personnel announcements at this time.” – Raj Shah, Principal Deputy Press Secretary
author: EamonJavers

text: How off the cuff was POTUS tariff announcement today? I’m told Trump was convinced by CEOs’ arguments, told them to wait there, ducked into a school safety event for 40 minutes, then went back to steel meeting + called in the press for the portion we saw on camera. Staff stunned.
author: EamonJavers

text: Amazing story here from @christinawilkie about a secretive polling operation connected to President Trump - AND the results of their internal polling: Half support military parade; voters don't agree w/Trump about Porter; + voters don't believe Nunes memo
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec on tariff hikes: This is something the president’s been talking about for some time. It should not come as any surprise to anyone.
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec on the president’s tariff announcement: “The president is announcing his intent to sign those actions next week. We’re not going to get into any more details until those details are finalized.”
author: EamonJavers

text: So after all the back and forth today about whether this announcement was coming - and after I was told it was coming and then told it was not - POTUS spontaneously decided to call in the pool and announce it anyway.
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump just told pool reporters that the US will be imposing tariffs next week.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH press pool has just been spontaneously invited into the steel event by the president. We should see some comments shortly.
author: EamonJavers

text: I am now told the meeting at the WH is ON for 11-ish this morning. But it is now NOT an announcement of new tariffs and instead a “discussion of the issue” involving steel and aluminum CEOs, members of the cabinet and WH staff.
author: EamonJavers

text: I am told that new tariffs are “probably where this is heading” but the administration is “not ready for an announcement” today.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH official confirms to me that there will be an announcement at 11 am on tariffs. Unclear what the specifics will be but there has been speculation about new levies on steel and aluminum.
author: EamonJavers

text: *for now*
author: EamonJavers

text: Put the Jared Kushner security downgrade together with tbe Hicks resignation, and the big winner inside the White House for now is John Kelly. A remarkable turnaround for a chief of staff who was fighting for his political life just a week ago.
author: EamonJavers

text: She is definitely seen as someone who could do the job. Certainly isn’t likely that they would bring in someone from the outside.
author: EamonJavers

text: It’s unclear how the president himself will react to her departure. By all accounts Hicks was one of his closest aides, closer even than some in his family. He relied on her to handle problems large and small. There’s no clear successor to that role at the WH.
author: EamonJavers

text: I’m told Hope Hicks officially told President Trump today of her decision to resign. She has told colleagues she intends to take some significant time off. Not clear what’s next for her.
author: EamonJavers

text: WH says Hicks’ exact departure date “is to be determined but it will be sometime in the next few weeks.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on Hicks: “Hope is outstanding and has done great work for the last three years. She is as smart and thoughtful as they come, a truly great person. I will miss having her by my side but when she approached me about pursuing other opportunities, I totally understood.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Statement from Hope Hicks now: “There are no words to adequately express my gratitude to President Trump. I wish the President and his administration the very best as he continues to lead our country.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Forgot to add: *Exclusive* *Must Credit*
author: EamonJavers

text: When you are the Vice President and you want to get a haircut at lunch, it makes for a lot of work for the Secret Service at the barber shop...
author: EamonJavers

text: Memo on Dina Powell’s return to Goldman Sachs says the former Trump White House official will have a new role with the firm: “Dina will focus on enhancing the firm's relationships with sovereign clients around the world.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Heh.
author: EamonJavers

text: Spoiler alert: Not shocking.
author: EamonJavers

text: Social media means it’s much easier to create swarms of phony bots than it is to create a few phony physical agents. Low stakes cover for online personas gets easier, but high stakes, elaborate cover stories are becoming more difficult to maintain:
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked Gary Cohn about share buybacks last fall. He said it would be ok if companies did them: “So look, if that happens, that’s fine. We know that that money will get invested right back into the economy, + drive jobs, drive economic growth, drive wages, and drive prosperity.”
author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec is asked if any WH personnel lost their access to classified information as a result of John Kelly’s new policy. She declined to answer, citing policy of not discussing security clearances.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on his lunch with the NRA: “These guys are patriots they’re great people and they want to do something, they’re going to do something.” Tells governors: “don’t worry about the NRA, they’re on our side. You guys- half of you - are so afraid of the NRA.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on the Parkland school deputies who failed to react to the ongoing massacre: “I really believe that I’d run in even if I didn’t have a weapon.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on guns: “Bump stocks, we’re writing that out, I’m writing that out, I don’t care if Congress” takes action.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on North Korea: “Russia is behaving badly because Russia is sending in what China is taking out.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump: “I think President Xi is unique, he is helping us with North Korea, who by the way wants to talk.”
author: EamonJavers

text: President Trump: “World Trade Organization makes it almost impossible for us to do business.”
