text: Good question! I’m not sure it’s a knowable material risk. Any celebrity could haul off and denounce any product at any time. BUT: an interesting Q for the SEC wd be whether she or her advisors sold or shorted the stock before the comment.
author: EamonJavers

text: Ha! You have no idea, man ...
author: EamonJavers

text: Weekend.
author: EamonJavers

text: More from Secret Service: “The female driver of the vehicle was immediately apprehended by Secret Service Uniformed Division Officers.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Secret Service statement now: “An individual driving a passenger vehicle struck a security barrier near the White House at 17th & E.”
author: EamonJavers

text: White House has locked the press office doors, which are typically open all day. A few moments ago, I saw three uniformed Secret Service officers running toward the residence.
author: EamonJavers

text: Secret Service tells me the security situation is elevated here at the White House. Uniformed officers are blocking off areas typically accessible to the press. Unclear if there’s anything significant going on.
author: EamonJavers

text: Chief of Staff John Kelly was looking on as the president said that.
author: EamonJavers

text: Turnbull on gun laws in Australia: “it’s such a completely different context historically, legally and so forth.” “We certainly don’t presume to provide policy or political advice on that matter here.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump on his son in law: “Jared is truly outstanding.” Calls him an extraordinary deal maker. Calls the security clearance system “broken” and says whether or not to give Jared a waiver on his security clearance will be up to chief of staff John Kelly. “I won’t make that call.”
author: EamonJavers

text: “I don’t think we’ve ever had a better relationship with China,” says President Trump. He says the only thing that could get in the way of it is trade.
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump, with tough words for Russia today: “What Russia Iran and Syria have done recently is a humanitarian disgrace.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump, on the armed officer who didn’t enter the school during the shooting in Florida: “That was not his finest moment, that I can tell you.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump, asked what he will do on school safety, cites background checks on guns as well as getting rid of bump stocks. Adds we need “offensive capability as well as defensive capability” within the schools.
author: EamonJavers

text: Turnbull to Trump: “We have been inspired, I must say, by your success in securing the passage of tax reform through the Congress.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump, to Turnbull, on Australia purchasing US military hardware: “You have very good taste in choosing our product.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump quotes Turnbull on the US-Australia relationship: “The United States and Australia celebrating 100 years of mate-ship.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Trump, on the officer who did not go in to stop the Parkland shooting: “When it came time to get in there and do something he didn’t have the courage or something happened... he certainly did a poor job.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Business Roundtable confirms JP Morgan’s Jamie Dimon had a private dinner w/President Trump at the White House last night, with Tom Linebarger of Cummins + Mark Costa of the Eastman Chemical Company. The BRT has been concerned with Administration’s rhetoric on NAFTA withdrawal.
author: EamonJavers

text: You’re right these charges don’t have anything specifically to do with Trump. But what the Trump camp has to worry about is possibility these charges are being used as pressure to get Gates or Manafort to flip and reveal other, Russia related, crimes they may be aware of.
author: EamonJavers

text: Among his other alleged problems, these allegations paint a picture of Manafort having a massive personal spending problem, nearly compulsively running up massive charges he could not pay and then scrambling to paper them over.
author: EamonJavers

text: 2. When the bank asked Manafort about $300,000 in overdue charges on his American Express card, Manafort allegedly blamed Gates for borrowing the card and said he’d get Gates to pay it back.
author: EamonJavers

text: 2. As recently as October 2017 Gates was still working on an amended tax filing for 2013. And allegedly lying to his tax preparer about not having any offshore accounts.
author: EamonJavers

text: That person didn’t like the look of the the falsified docs Manafort sent him, emailing: “Looks Dr’d. Can’t someone just do a clean excel doc and pdf to me??”
author: EamonJavers

text: Couple of interesting tidbits in this new document filed by Mueller today. 1. Manafort allegedly had an accomplice working inside a bank helping him get a bogus loan.

text: I asked Kevin Hassett about recent market volatility. He said it’s nothing to worry about: “Volatility is something that is to be expected... it's a regular thing in the stock market and it tends to go up when the market has gone up a lot as it has in response to our policies.”
author: EamonJavers

author: EamonJavers

text: NEW: White House official tells me WH is open to new ideas on guns, including: instead of banning some types of guns for all people (assault weapons ban), banning ALL guns for some people (mental illness). Internal debate ongoing, but this could also restrict access to handguns.
author: EamonJavers

text: These high school students are leading loud chants of “enough is enough” against gun violence now at the White House front gate.
author: EamonJavers

text: Large student protest against gun violence in front of the White House right now. Students holding a moment  of silence, and then chanting “hands up, don’t shoot.” Kids here from local High Schools including Blair, Whitman, BCC, Walter Johnson and others.

text: POTUS here seems to be criticizing Obama for tolerating Russian meddling, and Jeff Session(s) for the investigation. Still no criticism of Putin for ordering the meddling itself. https://twitter.com/realdonaldtrump/status/966312434100326400 …

text: So who is “Person A” from today’s Muller guilty plea? Another clue is in Statement of the Offense: Person A speaks Russian. Doc refers to “an email in Russian dated September 12, 2016 in which Person A asked VAN DER ZWAAN to contact Person A and to use an encrypted application.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sanders said there was some type of incident involving Russia that will become public soon: “just last week there was an incident that will be reported in the coming days, in another way that this president was tough on Russia.” I asked, but a WH official won’t say what this was.

text: Asked specifically what President Trump’s position now is on the assault weapons ban, which he once supported, @PressSec declines to answer. Says simply that she doesn’t have any announcement on that.

author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec, asked if the president acknowledges that Russia meddled in the election and did so on his behalf, says: “absolutely.” She adds it didn’t have an impact on the election and no one from the Trump campaign colluded.

text: This raises a couple of important questions: Who is “Person A” (and his family)? What was the email that was allegedly deleted in September of 2016? And finally: what impact does this have on Rick Gates’ decision to cooperate or not?

text: Rosenstein says there is no allegation in this indictment that any American was a knowing participant, no allegation that this activity changed the outcome of the 2016 presidential election.
author: EamonJavers

text: Rosenstein says the counts include: criminal conspiracy to defraud the United States; conspiracy to commit wire fraud and bank fraud; aggregated identity theft.

text: Per pool, WH press secretary Sarah Sanders said POTUS has been briefed today about the Mueller indictments that were handed down today.
author: EamonJavers

text: Rosenstein says this conspiracy was part of a larger operation. He says Internet Research Agency employed hundreds of people in its online operations with an annual budget of millions of dollars.
author: EamonJavers

text: Rosenstein: “the defendants allegedly conducted what they called information warfare against the United States.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Indictment: “Some defendants, posing as US persons and without revealing their Russian association, communicated with unwitting individuals associated with the Trump campaign and with other political activists to seek to coordinate political activities.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Just checked in with the press office. White House is offering no reaction yet to the Mueller indictments.
author: EamonJavers

text: Indictment: Certain of the Russian defendants “traveled to the United States under false pretenses” to collect intelligence to inform their operations. Russian goal: “to sow discord in the US political system, including the 2016 US presidential election.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Indictment says this Russian conspiracy to interfere in the US political system began in 2014 and included the 2016 election.
author: EamonJavers

text: Special Counsel’s office: “The indictment charges all of the defendants with conspiracy to defraud the United States, three defendants with conspiracy to commit wire fraud and bank fraud, and five defendants with aggravated identity theft.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Per press release, Indictment is against “13 Russian nationals and three Russian entities accused of violating U.S. criminal laws in order to interfere with U.S. elections and political processes.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Special Counsel’s office just dropped a new indictment. Details here:
author: EamonJavers

text: McDougal and he three men who allegedly acted as facilitators here would owe taxes on their payments, no? Nonpayment would be a point of leverage for any investigators looking into the matter, I’d think.
author: EamonJavers

text: Working in favor of the president is that the Edwards case ended in a muddle - acquitted on one charge, mistrial, and DOJ dropping case. Also campaign finance laws have been loosened dramatically since then.
author: EamonJavers

text: Seems like the risk to POTUS here is not a Clinton-style sex scandal (the culture has moved on) but an Edwards-style finance scandal. Concerns would be: Were all taxes paid? Do payments amount to undisclosed campaign donations under applicable law?
author: EamonJavers

author: EamonJavers

text: I’m on the scene now at the entrance to the NSA where we have reports of a shooting. Incident took place at a security gate. Not a lot of information coming out, but an NSA spokesman here says the situation is under control. No word on injuries, who may be in custody, etc.

author: EamonJavers

text: @PressSec, asked to explain why the press office said the WH could have handled the Porter situation better but the chief of staff said it was handled perfectly: “We’re humans, making us imperfect people.”

text: @PressSec on FBI timeline on whether or not the Porter investigation was still open, as the White House has said: The FBI portion was closed. The WH personnel security office, who is the one who makes an adjudication, was not finished.

text: He says the committee “will continue to work toward a conclusion” on whether there was collusion with the Russians by any campaign, individual or company.
author: EamonJavers

text: Chairman Burr says “the special counsel is not the only investigation that’s going on in Washington.” Says Senate Intel is “hopefully wrapping up” on some issues. Will share an overview on findings before primaries and hold a public hearing on election security.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Harris asks FBI Director Wray whether he would turn over Russia investigation info if Trump asked for it. Wray: “I am not going to discuss the investigation with the president much less provide information to him.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Cotton asks CIA Director Pompeo about reports that up to 200 Russian mercenaries were recently killed in Syria.  “I’ll leave it to the Department of Defense to talk about what transpired there,” Pompeo says.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Cotton asks FBI Director Wray if Christopher Steele worked for Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska while writing the Steele Dossier. Wray says there isn’t much he can say on that in an unclassified hearing.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Heinrich asks about WH staff without clearances having access to classified material. DNI Coats: “I’m not in a position to discuss what individual situations are.” But he adds access “has to be limited” for people with red flags in the clearance process.
author: EamonJavers

text: FBI Director Wray dismisses Trump criticism of political bias in the FBI. Says “our folks are pretty sturdy.” Asked if he believes there is bias in the FBI, he says “no.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Collins asks Wray about Trump’s criticism of the FBI. Wray says FBI is “the finest group of professionals.” Cites their “integrity, professionalism and grit.” Says “Although you would never know it from watching the news we have more than two investigations.”
author: EamonJavers

text: FBI Director Wray gives a new timeline on Rob Porter vetting: says FBI submitted a report on the investigation in March 2017. Completed background investigation in July. FBI received a request for follow up in November. And obtained new information recently.
author: EamonJavers

text: Warner asks intel chiefs for a yes or no answer on if they think Russia will try to interfere in the 2018 elections. They all answer yes.
author: EamonJavers

text: Coats tells senators he is concerned that “our increasing fractious political process” is threatening to impact intel community’s ability to defend the nation. He cites the growing national debt as a threat to national security.
author: EamonJavers

text: Coats goes beyond the written document in his testimony, adding: “There should be no doubt that Russia perceived its past efforts as successful” and sees the 2018 midterm elections as a target.
author: EamonJavers

text: He is the leader of the Intelligence Community as DNI. The rest will answer questions on the record from the senators. But he gets to go first with an opener.
author: EamonJavers

text: Statement from DNI Dan Coats. He says: “We expect Russia to continue using propaganda, social media, false-flag personas, sympathetic spokespeople, and other means of influence to try to exacerbate social and political fissures in the United States.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Yep. He just gaveled in the hearing. Did not touch on Russia investigation or elections in his opening statement.
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Richard Burr asks FBI director Wray about counter intelligence and security risks from Chinese telecom providers like Huawei and ZTE which are “widely understood to have extraordinary ties to the Chinese government.”
author: EamonJavers

text: He will also say: “There have been some, aided and abetted by Russian internet bots and trolls, who have attacked the integrity of the FBI and the Department of Justice. This is a dangerous trend.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Sen. Mark Warner will say “We’ve had more than a year to get our act together and address the threat posed by Russia and implement a strategy to deter future attacks” on US elections. “But we still do not have a plan.”
author: EamonJavers

text: Also ... the folks from the Code Pink protest group are here and getting prime seats. So stand by for interruptions!

text: Gearing up for Senate Intelligence Committee hearing this morning. FBI director Chris Wray, CIA Director Mike Pompeo and other intel leaders will be here. Official topic is “Worldwide threats” but its a good bet the Russia investigation will come up.

text: POTUS here casting doubt on spousal abuse allegations against Rob Porter. But his chief of staff, John Kelly, told me yesterday he learned the allegations were “true” on Tuesday night. So does the White House believe the allegations or not?

text: So in his comments just now, Kelly said he learned Tuesday night “That the accusations were true. 40 minutes later he was gone.” I asked if that’s when he learned about the picture and he said: “ I didn't even know about that.”
author: EamonJavers

text: John Kelly just told me + a couple reporters, “In November, I got an update about some of the investigations, and the update was that there were some things that needed to be looked into and literally that was it. And Tuesday night I found out. And that's what I've been saying.”
author: EamonJavers

text: A White Hosue official is now waiving us off a report that General Kelly expressed a willingness to resign today.

text: Keyyy said he found out Tuesday night “that the accusations were true.  40 minutes later he was gone.” But POTUs today said he takes Porter’s denial into consideration.
author: EamonJavers

text: Just spoke to Chief of Staff Kelly in the West Wing. I asked him how he’s feeling as the week comes to an end. He said “Good. Accomplished a lot.” He said he first learned of the Rob Porter allegations Tuesday night, and 40 minutes later he was gone.
author: EamonJavers

text: Per Pool, President Trump commented on the Rob Porter ouster: “We wish him well. He worked very hard....Obviously a tough time for him... he also as you probably know he says he’s innocent and I think you have to remember that.. he said very strongly yesterday he’s innocent.”

text: Pool reports the event is the president meeting in the Oval with a supporter and the supporter’s father who had fallen on times and received help from the President.

text: White House has called the pool reporters for an unscheduled and unexpected event at the White House right now. Not clear what’s up but there could be some news coming. Or not!
author: EamonJavers

text: Michael Lewis: “The White House press briefing room sounds like an exciting place to visit, but the minute you are in it you sort of wish you weren’t. It has the cramped uncared-for feel of a public toilet, or a cable television green room.”

text: And he said: “And corporate earnings are high. And we believe that these long-term fundamentals demonstrate a healthy economy.”

text: Here’s WH spox Raj Shah’s full answer to my question about today’s 1,000 point drop by the Dow: “Well, the President, like the rest of the White House, is concerned about long-term economic indicators and factors. And the fundamentals, in terms of the long term, are very strong.”

text: 5. There was apparently some wrangling over redactions to this memo. But a lot of this if information that has been in the public domain for a long time. So what was it that the FBI wanted to redact here?
author: EamonJavers

text: 4. What did the initial FISA application say about Papadopoulos? This memo simply says it “mentions information regarding” him. What information?
author: EamonJavers

text: 3. Did any FISA judge demand an explanation for this? The judges read the papers and the funding sources have been public for a while now. If the judges felt misled, they could have complained. Did they?
author: EamonJavers

text: 2. Why didn’t the FBI note Steele’s financial backing (from a Republican leaning group and then the Dems)? Sources familiar with FISA tell me that kind of info is usually included, because it goes to motivation.
author: EamonJavers

text: First cut thoughts on the memo: 1. A lot will depend on what it means that the dossier played “an essential part” in the FISA application. How essential? What other classified information, if any, was presented that we don’t see here?

text: BUT, this president didn’t get where he is by listening to traditional political advice. He sees himself as a counterpuncher. So we’ll see.

text: Traditional political advice would be not to release today. The news cycle is dominated by largely glowing reviews of the SOTU and POTUS soundbites playing on all channels. Why replace that with any Russia related news?

text: Is the White House going to release the memo soon? Conflicting signals on that, but Sarah Sanders says it is still in a review process and no decision is made.

text: So with the Dow down more than  300 points this afternoon, will President Trump still be able to brag about the stock market in the State of the Union tonight? I get the sense the West Wing thinks he can - a one day dip doesn’t take away from a year of big gains.
author: EamonJavers

text: ... the personalities here, particularly Warren Buffett and Jeff Bezos, are seen in Republican Washington as big Dems or hostile to Trump. So how does that shake out? I dunno.

text: President Trump statement now: “Steve Bannon has nothing to do with me or my Presidency. When he was fired, he not only lost his job, he lost his mind.” This is as scorching a statement as I have ever seen from a president about a high level former aide.
author: EamonJavers

text: Will the Trump Organization pay tax cut bonuses the president has praised other companies for paying?Update: @PressSec referred my question to the Trump Org. An executive there referred me to the Trump Org press email. And the press email has not - so far - responded.
author: EamonJavers

text: This is very, very strong stuff from Bannon today. Calls the Don Jr meeting with the Russians “treasonous” and “unpatriotic.” How will the White House respond? https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/03/donald-trump-russia-steve-bannon-michael-wolff …
author: EamonJavers

text: I don’t know. Presumably, investigators have asked them not to release info while committees and special counsel work: it could spook sources, alert targets, or cause political reactions based on incomplete info. But if Glenn calls me, I’ll pick up the phone.
author: EamonJavers

text: Could be. My sense is the Papadopoulos saga has yet to be fully revealed. I don’t know who it was, but it is intriguing that someone inside the Trump camp was allegedly reporting to the FBI in real time.
author: EamonJavers

text: Fusion GPS op-ed raises a question: Who was the source inside the Trump camp who reported to the FBI? “The dossier was taken so seriously because it corroborated reports the bureau had received from other sources, including one inside the Trump camp.” https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/02/opinion/republicans-investigation-fusion-gps.html …
author: EamonJavers

text: They have a press “drop box” email address and I have also emailed a couple employees there directly. No response so far.
author: EamonJavers

text: Here’s what the president Tweeted about other companies today: “Companies are giving big bonuses to their workers because of the Tax Cut Bill. Really great!”
author: EamonJavers

text: I’ve emailed some people at the Trump Organization to find out their plans. No response yet.
author: EamonJavers

text: I also asked if POTUS thinks all companies should pay bonuses. Sarah: “I think he certainly hopes that companies will either give bonuses to their employees or somehow reinvest+bring business back into this country. That was one of the big purposes and goals of the tax cut bill.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I asked @PressSec if employees of the president’s own companies would get bonuses this year given POTUS praise of other companies that paid based on the tax bill. She said she can’t answer from the briefing room, it’s a question for the Trump Organization directly.
author: EamonJavers

text: New Year, new Trump photos gracing the walls of the West Wing: Picture of Trump and Xi Jinping appears to be gone - or moved- replaced by a picture of Trump and Orrin Hatch. Other framed pics include Trump presenting a Purple Heart and recent WH scenes.

author: EamonJavers

text: WH says President Trump will sign the tax bill today, but will do it off camera and in private. So you will not see pictures of the ink on the paper today.

text: WH National Economic Council Deputy Director Jeremy Katz - Gary Cohn’s #2 - is leaving the Administration. Last day will be Jan. 5. Going out on a high note after tax bill passes.
author: EamonJavers

text: SAO said “You have to be more specific abt people. I know we love to learn the more generic points of palace intrigue than the finer points of policy sometimes, but we have a really good team here. And it would have to be individual by individual + I don't really play that game.”
author: EamonJavers

text: I re-asked the question, and SAO said: “But the question implies that it was, so I'm asking why you think it was a mistake.”
author: EamonJavers

text:
In a WH background briefing today, I asked a Senior Administration Official if the President made any hiring mistakes this year, given all the staffers who were fired or resigned in 2017. 
SAO said: “No, the President didn't make a mistake. Why would you think that?”
author: EamonJavers

text: Goldman Sachs changes econ forecast based on tax bill: GDP forecasts for 2018 and 2019 up, by 0.3pp and 0.2pp, respectively, on a Q4/Q4 basis (to 2.6% and 1.7%). Year-end 2018 unemployment rate forecast lower by two tenths to 3.5%. They expect deficit to rise.

text: Tom Bossert says the North Koreans saw raising money through WannaCry as an ancillary benefit, but their goal was simply to create havoc. He said if they wanted to raise money, they would have unlocked computers of those who paid ransoms.

Salaries and benefits: $1.7M
